metadata.description: The Central Asia Reanalysis (CAR) dataset is generated based on the Weather Research and Forecast (WRF) model version 4.1.2 and WRF Data Assimilation (WRFDA) Version 4.1.2. Variables include temperature,, pressure, wind speed, precipitation and radiation. The reanalysis is established through cyclic assimilation, which performs data assimilation every 6 hours by 3DVAR. The assimilated data include conventional atmospheric observation and satellite radiation data. The main source of conventional data is  Global Teleconnection System (GTS), including surface station, automatic station, radiosonde and aircraft report, and the observation elements include temperature, air pressure, wind speed and humidity. Satellite observations include retrievals and radiation data, The retrievals are mainly atmospheric motion vectors from polar orbiting meteorological satellites (NOAA-18, NOAA-19, MetOP-A and MetOP-B)  and resampled to a horizontal resolution of 54km; the radiation data includes microwave radiation from MSU, AMSU and MHS and HIRS infrared radiation data. The simulation applies nesting with a horizontal resolution of 27km and 9km respectively, a total of 38 layers in the vertical direction and a top of the model layer of 10hPa. The lateral boundary conditions of the model are provided by ERA-Interim every 6 hours. The physical schemes used in the model are Thompson microphysics scheme, CAM radiation scheme, MYJ boundary layer scheme, Grell convection scheme and Noah land surface model. The data covers five countries in Central Asia, including Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, as well as lakes in Central Asia, such as Caspian Sea, Aral Sea, Balkash lake and Isaac lake, which can be used for the study of climate, ecology and hydrology in the region. Compared with gauge-based precipitation in Central Asia, the simulation by CAR shows similar performance with MSWEP ( a merged product) and outperforms ERA5 and ERA-Interim.
metadata.instructions:
The data storage format is NetCDF, which is a self describing file. The data file itself contains the description information The name of the data file is "var_car_freq_res_yyyy. nc". The static information (terrain height, land use, vegetation cover, etc.) file name is "geo_res.nc". "var" represents variables, for example, "ta" represents mean temperature, "ws" represents wind speed, "ps" represents surface pressure, "lw" represents surface downward longwave radiation, "sw" represents surface downward shortwave radiation, "pr" represents precipitation, "tmax" represents daily maximum temperature and "tmin" represents daily minimum temperature. "freq" and "res" stand for temporal and horizontal resolution respectively. Daily and monthly data at resolutions of 27km and 9km are available. "yyyy" stands for year.
It is recommended to use NCL or Python related modules (such as xarray) to process data.

Feature Specification.Answer: cyclic assimilation, WRF model, WRFDA assimilation system, 3DVAR every 6 hours, conventional atmospheric observations, satellite radiance data, conventional data from GTS, manual and automatic stations, soundings, aircraft reports, observed variables include temperature, pressure, wind speed, humidity, retrieval data from polar-orbiting meteorological satellites, 54 km horizontal resolution, microwave radiance from MSU, AMSU, MHS, infrared radiance from HIRS

Definition.Question: What is '再分析资料' (reanalysis data) in the context of climate datasets?
Definition.Answer: 再分析资料 (reanalysis data) refers to datasets created by assimilating historical atmospheric observations into a consistent model framework to produce comprehensive and consistent records of past climate conditions. In the context of the 中亚大湖区气候再分析资料数据集, it involves using the WRF model and WRFDA assimilation system to integrate conventional and satellite data every 6 hours through a 3DVAR assimilation process, providing detailed information on variables such as temperature, pressure, wind speed, precipitation, and radiation.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the 中亚大湖区气候再分析资料数据集 compare to those used in other regional climate reanalysis datasets in terms of satellite data assimilation and resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The 中亚大湖区气候再分析资料数据集 uses a combination of conventional atmospheric observations and satellite radiance data, with satellite observations including retrieval data from polar-orbiting meteorological satellites resampled to a 54 km horizontal resolution. The dataset employs a nested simulation approach with horizontal resolutions of 27 km and 9 km, and vertical resolution of 38 layers, assimilating data every 6 hours using 3DVAR. In comparison, other regional climate reanalysis datasets may use different satellite data sources, assimilation frequencies, resolutions, or physical schemes, which can affect their accuracy and applicability for different regional studies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary reasons for integrating both conventional atmospheric observations and satellite radiance data in climate reanalysis datasets for Central Asia?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The integration of conventional atmospheric observations and satellite radiance data in climate reanalysis datasets for Central Asia is primarily to enhance the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the dataset. Conventional data sourced from GTS, including observations from manned and automated stations, radiosondes, and aircraft reports, provide detailed atmospheric information such as temperature, pressure, wind speed, and humidity. Satellite data, including cloud-drift winds and microwave and infrared radiance data from polar-orbiting meteorological satellites, offer additional spatial coverage and information not available from ground-based observations. This combination allows for more accurate modeling of atmospheric conditions, especially in areas with sparse observational coverage, and improves the reanalysis dataset's ability to capture regional climate dynamics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures involved in using WRF model and WRFDA assimilation system to create a regional climate reanalysis dataset for Central Asia, and how can these methods be adapted to incorporate additional observational data sources?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involve utilizing the WRF model version 4.1.2 and WRFDA assimilation system version 4.1.2 to establish a reanalysis dataset for Central Asia. This process includes using a cycling assimilation method, where 3DVAR assimilation is performed every 6 hours. The assimilation incorporates conventional atmospheric observations and satellite radiance data. Conventional data primarily come from GTS, including manned and automated stations, radiosondes, and aircraft reports, with observed elements like temperature, pressure, wind speed, and humidity. Satellite observations include retrieval data and radiative data, resampled to a 54 km horizontal resolution. For modeling, a double-layer nesting approach is used with horizontal resolutions of 27 km and 9 km, and 38 vertical layers up to 10 hPa. The side boundary conditions are provided by the ERA-Interim reanalysis with a 6-hourly analysis field. The physical schemes include the Thompson microphysics scheme, CAM radiation scheme, MYJ boundary layer scheme, Grell convection scheme, and Noah land surface model. These procedures can be adapted to incorporate additional data sources by adjusting the assimilation cycle to include more observational datasets or integrating newer satellite retrieval and radiative products.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies and resources enable the creation of high-resolution regional reanalysis data for Central Asia, particularly those incorporating both conventional atmospheric observations and satellite radiation data?
Enablement.Answer: The creation of high-resolution regional reanalysis data for Central Asia is enabled by using the WRF model version 4.1.2 and the WRFDA assimilation system version 4.1.2. This involves cyclic assimilation every 6 hours with 3DVAR, utilizing conventional atmospheric observations and satellite radiation data. Conventional data are sourced from GTS, including manual and automated stations, radiosondes, and aircraft reports, with observed elements like temperature, pressure, wind speed, and humidity. Satellite observations incorporate polar-orbiting meteorological satellites (NOAA-18, NOAA-19, METOP-A, and METOP-B) for cloud motion vectors and microwave radiation data such as MSU, AMSU, and MHS, along with HIRS infrared radiation data. The simulation employs a dual-nested approach with horizontal resolutions of 27 km and 9 km and 38 vertical levels, with boundary conditions provided by ERA-Interim analysis fields. Physics schemes used include the Thompson microphysics scheme, CAM radiation scheme, MYJ boundary layer scheme, Grell convection scheme, and Noah land surface model.
